entry.title: SOME RECORDS ON NEC
entry.content:
Last Sunday afternoon, 2020 21st Dec, I finished my NEC exam.

I have prepared for the exam since I decided to take part in it. When the words ‘EXAM IS OVER’ appeared on my screen, I was a little bit disappointed because there were many questions which I found I could not do anything with.

About four months ago, when I talked to my Economics teacher Ms.Cindy, I heard about NEC for the first time. She told me that NEC is National Economics Challenge and advantages and disadvantages of it. I decided to take part in it as I discovered that I am really interested in Economics.

Then, I discussed with my friends. We founded a group called ‘Together Group’ because we hoped that everyone in our group can always be together and support each other during preparation.

At the beginning, we four were all very positive, energetic and active. Tiffany found some lessons online, while Leo borrowed some books like Baron. Yuki and I collected and sorted all the materials we had. We even attended the CCA for NEC every Tuesday afternoon. This was the most impressive part in this activity, as Together Group gave me the feeling of a family.

Gradually, two of us started to lose confidence as other students are stronger than us in Economics. Yuki and I kept on taking classes and reading Mankind’s Principle of Economy. During this stage, I noticed that it became easier for me to understand some knowledge we learn in normal classes by Ms.Cindy.

Before the exam, I knew that it was almost impossible for my Together Group to get into next turn as it counted the top three marks in a group. However, I didn’t choose to give up because for a very long time I have believe that after the winter, there will always be the spring and when I do a thing, especially as a group member, I need to try my best to finish it because it is my responsibility and if I do, I can grow stronger. Several night before the exam, I stayed up late until mid-night and wrote a pile of notes. When collecting them after exam, strong sense of pride and achievement.

I haven’t get the result of the exam. However, I believed that everything will be well although we may not get into next turn to take part in the NEC China Finals, because I have done my best and insisted the belief in my heart for years.

From NEC Preliminary, I got to know that when I decide to do something, it is better for me to finish it without distractions, because when I act as this, I will become stronger and stronger.

entry.title: IGCSE Economics Mind Map Section1 The Basic Economic Problems
entry.content:
The nature of the economic problem

Needs vs Wants

  • Needs are essential goods and services required for survival
  • Wants are goods and services that are not necessary for survival

Economics goods vs Free good

  • Economics goods have opportunity cost.
  • Definition: Economic goods is a product which requires resources to produce it and therefore has an opportunity cost. EG. carpet
  • Free goods don’t have opportunity cost.
  • Definition: Free goods is a product which dos not require any resources to make it and so does not have an opportunity cost. EG. sunshine, water in a river
    • If the water is processed for drinking or irrigation of fields, it becomes an economic goods.

Economic problem

  • Definition: The people’s wants are unlimited, but the resources are limited.( Scarcity )
  • Everyone has to make choices because of scarcity.

Opportunity cost

Resource allocation therefore involves deciding how best to use scarce resources to satisfy as many needs and wants as possible.

Definition: Opportunity cost is the cost of choice. It means the best alternative foregone when making a choice. It is the cost measured in terms of the next best choice given up when making a choice.

Production possibility curve

Definition: PPC shows the maximum combined output of two or more products a firm or an entire economy can produce with its available resources.

locations of points

  • on the curve

    • efficient
    • attainable

  • inside the curve

    • inefficient
    • attainable

  • outside the curve

    • unattainable

shift

  • outside

    • increase in resources
    • increase in productivity
    • improve technology

  • inside

    • decrease in the productive capacity( quantity or quality) of a country

PPCs are therefore a useful way of showing the opportunity cost of producing more of one product in terms of how much of another must be given up

Factors of production

LAND

[SYN] Natural Resources

  • Definition: Land is gifts of nature available for production. eg. land itself, coal, rainforests, fish
  • Renewable & Unrenewable
  • Rewards: Rent

LABOUR

[SYN] Human capital

  • Definition: Labour is the human effort used in producing goods and services.
  • Improved productivity—-Technology, education and training
  • Rewards: Wages

CAPITAL

  • Definition: Capital is human-made goods used in production. eg. offices, factories, machinery, railway and tools.

  • Capital goods vs Consumer goods

    • determine who is the user and the purpose of its use

  • Rewards: Interest

ENTERPRISE

  • Definition: Enterprise is the skill a business person required to combine and manage successfully the other three factors of production and ability to undertake risk and to make decisions in business. （Do not include managers)
  • Rewards: Profits

Mobility

  • Land

    • occupationally mobile
    • geographically immobile

  • Labour

    • occupationally immobile

      • lack of information
      • lack of appropriate skills and qualifications

    • geographically immobile

      • differences in the price and availability of housing in different areas and countries
      • family ties
      • differences in educational systems in different areas and countries
      • lack of information
      • restrictions on the movement of workers

  • Capital

    • varies according to the type of capital goods

  • Enterprise(Entrepreneurs)

    • Most mobile FOP

entry.title: SOME RECORDS ON Physics Bowl
entry.content:
On 27th March, around two o’clock in the afternoon, I finished 2021 Physics Bowl.

That was a nice afternoon which is windy and cloudy. The paper was not very hard as the Electromagnetism didn’t appear too many times which is my drawback among all pieces of knowledge. The boy sitting on my left, finished his paper very quickly and seemed to be very confident about his answers.

I was a little bit upset that day. Two things were always on my mind.

To be honest, during the long preparation for Physics Bowl, I gave up half way instead of insisting on training past papers and getting through the book after class. I still remembered the first lesson of Physics Bowl taken by me at the beginning of the first semester of Senior1. During that time, Physics was my favourite subject and I even set it as my target major in the university. However, I started to learn more about both Physics and Economics. Economics is a new subject to me which I refused to study before entry of senior high school but was deeply attracted after getting to understand some basic knowledge. By contrast, it was unbelievable that it began hard for me to understand the complicated concepts in Physics which ran out all my patience and interest. With further study in Economics competition, more time was devoted to Economics instead of Physics. It was a process that happened during a long period, but I still remembered clearly some small moments like I was almost driven crazy by Physics for the first time. From then on, I knew that the story between Physics and I may be near the ending. Another thing happened is that I did some program study those days and read more books about both Nature Science and Social Science especially Economics. A strange feeling of thirsty of concentrating more on Economics came to my heart due to the books I read. I talked to my parents, counsellor and Economics teacher several times. They all hoped that I could insist on what I really love.

AMC teaches me the real meaning of opportunity costs. Physics Bowl may teach me something about giving up.

Many teachers say I am a girl who has a strong demand for perfection, because it is common for me to take part in all the meaningful activities and play an active role in finishing tasks, in order to get satisfying result, even if I dislike the activities or lack time. During the preparation, everyday I was so busy to deal with every details in my life as many events had similar date, that it was difficult for me to calm down and go through the day again, so I decided to give up something to chill myself and reflect more.

I decided to give up Physics Bowl as a result of a lack of incentive of further study due to decreasing interest in Physics. Maybe we can regard this decision as a kind of releasing myself.

I would always be thankful for Physics Bowl as it helped me to discover that maybe it is so suitable for me to spend the rest of time learning Physics but Economics. Also, it provided me with a chance to think about giving up which is a thing I had never though about before. I don’t think that giving up equals to escaping. It is that choose to not choose something in our life because we may hope to choose other things. This is kind of admiration of being ourselves.

entry.title: SOME RECORDS ON AMC and AIME
entry.content:
On 5th and 11th February, I finished my two AMC exams.

AMC is American Mathematics Competition. It is one of the most popular and welcomed maths competition all over the world. During primary school, I used to take part in AMC8 and receive a relative high score(Top 2.5%). As a result, after attending senior high school, AMC became one of my after-class activities as well, because I wanted to challenge myself through it.

During my process of preparation, I felt a little bit lonely from time to time, as there were only a few students in my class choosing to try AMC12 which is beyond the current syllabus.

I tried to talk with August who prepared for AMC12 too, about the exam preparing. We discussed questions from time to time after that. Now, we are good friends. This is the most impressive part of the activity.

I started to understand that although we may compete with each other during the competition, it is still important and possible for us to cooperate, as a result of friendship. Competition is more than competing. August and I received satisfied scores. I got 103.5points in AMC10A and 117points in AMC12B.

Additionally, through AMC, one thing has become clearer than before. The process of improving, challenging and studying may be lonely because everyone makes different decision during this period. For example, my best friend Estella chose to forgo AMC as she wanted to take part in FBLA more. Another example is that during the last preparing day, August and I still had a lot of things which we had not learnt and understood. We chose to study different areas.

From my point of view, the aloneness is one of the lessons we need to learn during our studying time.

Fortunately, I got the chance to take part in AIME(America Invitational Mathematics Examination). However, something unexpected happened. The date of AIME was conflicted with my school IGCSE mock examination. I said to myself several time, “Mock is more important as it is the first time for me to experience international examinations hold by CAIE and mock exam will be the source of GPA of this semester.” Every time the sense of not convinced also came to my heart as it really took me hours and hours learning maths knowledge and going through past papers.

Finally, I decided to give up preparing for AIME to save time for mock exams. After handing in my AIME paper, I got to know that this time I must have been failed to achieve anything. It was near 8 p.m. when AIME was done. Block 1912 opposite my school was still full of music sounds and colourful lights. Suddenly, one concept which I learnt in Economics came to my mind——opportunity cost and made me feel relived.

Everyone has limited time and energy, but I always long for finishing everything which is unattainable and impossible. As a result, it is necessary for me to make a decision on what to do. Opportunity cost is the next best choice foregone when making a decision. I still remember the words which were said by my Economics teacher Ms. Cindy when I told her that I would switch my future major from Physics to Economics. She said that, “Every decision or choice has an opportunity cost. I simply hope that you can consider the thing carefully before making a decision.”

Perhaps to Estella, she though FBLA was more important than AMC so she made such a decision that high prize was rewarded to her by FBLA but not so good performance was shown by her in AMC. To me, I still hope to achieve higher marks in IGCSE instead of AIME.

To sum up, I will always remember AMC and AIME of this year. They provides me with a chance to experience the concept of opportunity costs by myself instead of leaving it only as a piece of knowledge in my Economics books.

Meantime, after seeing the lights and hearing the sounds from Block 1912, I am not regretted about my decision anymore, although a total of only 4 marks was achieved by me in AIME, because I still realised that life sucks, so it may be better for me to be cute and enjoy and try to get understand the tastes of life more, instead of giving myself too much press to spend time seeing the around world.

entry.title: Thinking on The Fuzzy and The Techie
entry.content:
This book mainly talks about the relationship between the Liberal Arts and digital world.

What is the Liberal Arts? Liberal arts generally covers four areas including the natural sciences, social sciences, arts and humanities. At present, there are some liberal arts colleges in the U.S.A. which are undergraduate institutions of high education, for example the Wellesley College. From my point of view, liberal arts plays an essential role in our society. First of all, liberal arts can also be described as “psychology”. All the liberal arts majors aim to research the way in which humans consider things and the influence on the society caused by these consideration. From example, Economics is the study which looks for the mentality of the consumers, producers and governments in a specific market. In addition, liberal arts also represents interdisciplinary study and research. A liberal arts education encourages students to integrates different areas of study, making students to explore a variety of subjects. This results in students can consider one problem from multiple perspectives.

What is STEM? STEM stands for science, technology, engineering and maths. These subjects promote the development of technology which has a wider meaning than the technology in STEM. This will result in a better living standard. For example, it is possible for us to print a house in a relative short time with a 3D printer which requires a long time with plenty of workers to finish.

I must point out that STEM and liberal arts coincide in some areas. For example, they both cover the natural science which include chemistry, physics and other subjects.

The first thing I want to talk about is the interdisciplinary studies. This is defined as the combination of two or more academic disciplines into one activity. When it happens, something is created by thinking across boundaries between different subjects. At present, a variety of interdisciplinary studies appears in our society for example the PPE ( Politics, Philosophy and Economics) and HSPS (Human, Social, and Political Sciences). During interdisciplinary studies, students can easily develop the skills of critical thinking, communication, creative problem solving, self-expression, innovative research and lifelong learning. This can promote the digital worlds as when we start an Internet company, everything needs to be considered detailedly without any mistakes. These skills will work. The study of liberal arts is mainly the interdisciplinary studies. To sum up, from the aspect of the interdisciplinary studies and the skills, the liberal arts is able to promote digital world.

The nest thing drawing my attention is the replacement by the technology. In the book, the author describes the situation in which the some workers are replaced by the technology, for example, the proportion of farmers has decreased a lot during the past century in America because of the development of automation. I still remembered the words which were said by my junior high school head teacher Mr. Cao. He said that in the future, we needed to concentrate in one areas to be more professional, because this could help us avoid being replaced by others. With the development of technology, the main problem has turned from replacement by the other workers to replacement by the technology. The times changed. Our competitor has changed from people to machines. I don’t mean that we need to reject all the technology. The most important thing is how to balance the relationship between technology and workers. From my point of view, overuse of technology may result in an increase in unemployment. Unskilled people may find it more and more difficult to earn a living. Skilled people must be more and more professional to keep their job. However, liberal arts can solve this problem in some ways. If everyone takes liberal arts, they will learn to think independently and critically. This results in that everyone has clear direction of self-development. Digital world can progress better in such social environment.

The last thing is people oriented. Why is liberal arts important? Except the reasons mentioned above, another vital reason is that liberal arts is kind of human based. In modern society, the technology can work out a variety of solutions of a problem, but it is difficult for them to choose, because the choices are made with consideration for a lot of factors, not only the costs and opportunity costs, as our society is made up of over seven billion people. A company which has workers can not survive without people oriented. After a long-time squeeze, people may do some crazy things. Everything will change, if the company is people oriented, Google discovered that if bosses greeted workers enthusiastically in the morning, the productivity would show an increase.

In conclusion, the liberal arts plays a positive role in the Digital World. However, I think liberal arts can influence all the fields optimistically because of its features.

What is infinity? In wikipedia, infinity represents something that is boundless or endless, or else something that is larger than any real or natural number.

To be honest, I don’t understand every detail in the book. Although this book was written about a half century ago, some knowledge is not the most famous at the moment. However, this book is still not out of date actually.

In the second chapter, the author introduces the four-dimensional space. This part becomes more difficult for me to understand as I have a poor ability of imagining. The most unforgettable thing in the first two parts is an annotation given by the translator. The annotation is given during the author describe the four colour theorem. It says “This theorem has been proved during 1970s by the computer.”

What does this mean?

We all know that science has been developed rapidly in the past century. More and more theorems help people extend the science research. It becomes more difficult for non-professional people to learn, although in modern society, more convenient ways have been designed to learn new knowledge. Online reading is a good example. It is worth noting that, in these years, the things which have been develop do not only include science and technology, but also the ability of people to learn. entry.title: IGCSE Economics Mind Map Section2 The Allocation of Resources
entry.content:
Market

Demand

  • Definition: Demand is the willingness and ability to buy a product

  • Law of demand: Quantity demanded and price are inversely related. When the price falls, the demand rises.(Normal Goods)

  • Differentiate

    • Quantity demanded

      • Actual quantity at a certain price

    • Demand

      • Not a quantity but all the relation between price and quantity demanded

  • Determinations

    • Price

      • Change in quantity demanded

        • Extension in demand

          • Definition: Movement along the demand curve when quantity demanded increases due to a fall in the price of the product itself.

        • Contraction in demand

          • Definition: Movement along the demand curve when quantity demanded decreases due to an increase in the price of the product itself.

    • Non-price

      • Change in demand

        • Increase

          • Definition: a rise in quantity demanded at any given price, causing the demand curve to shift to the right

        • Decrease

          • Definition: a decrease in quantity demanded at any given price, causing the demand curve to shift to the left

      • Price of related goods

        • Substitutes

          • Definition: It is a product that can be used in place of another. They can satisfy the same want
          • price of substitute increase–>demand for substitute contract–>demand for the product increase–>price of the product increase

        • Complements

          • Definition: It is a product that is used together with another product. Complements are in joint
          • price of complement increase–>demand for complement contract–>demand for the product reduce–>price of the product decrease

      • Income

        • Normal goods

          • When income increases, the demand for it increases

        • Inferior goods

          • When income decrease, the demand for it increases

      • Successful advertising

        • More heavily, more demand

      • Interest rate

        • An increase in interest rate creates incentive for consumers to save more and purchase less, so the demand decreases

      • Population

        • An increase in population, an increase in demand

      • Fashion, taste, habit

      • Other factors

        • change in weather conditions
        • expectation
        • special events

Supply

  • Definition: It is the willingness and ability of firms to produce and sell a product.

  • Law of supply: Quantity supplied and price are directly related. When the price falls, the supply rises.

  • Differentiate

    • Quantity supply

      • Actual quantity at a certain price

    • Supply

      • Not a quantity but all the relation between price and quantity supplied

  • Determinations

    • Price

      • Change in quantity supplied

        • Extension in supply

          • Definition: Movement along the supply curve when quantity supplied increases due to a rise in the price of the product itself.

        • Contraction in supply

          • Definition: Movement along the supply curve when quantity supplied decreases due to a decrease in the price of the product itself.

    • Non-price

      • Change in supply

        • Increase

          • Definition: a rise in quantity supplied at any given price, causing the supply curve to shift to the right

        • Decrease

          • Definition: a decrease in supplied demanded at any given price, causing the supply curve to shift to the left

      • Costs of production

        • An increase in the costs of production results in an decrease in supply(want a higher price for it)

      • Improvement in technology

        • raise productivity, reduce costs of production, increase supply

      • Taxes

        • Only direct taxes on firms including corporation taxes, and indirect tax including VAT and excise duty
        • an increase in tax–>more expensive to supply a product and reduce supply

      • Subsidies

        • an increase in subsidy–>cheaper to supply, decrease in costs of production and increase supply

      • Price of other products

        • firms may choose to produce more other goods produced by the firms as an increase in other goods’ price and supply(opportunity cost)

      • Other factors

        • weather conditions and health of livestock and crops
        • disasters and wars
        • discoveries and depletions of commodities

Price determination

  • Definition: Equilibrium price is the price where quantity demanded and quantity supplied are equal. There is no pressure to change the price.

  • Disquilibrium

    • Definition: It is the situation where quantity demanded and quantity supplied are not equal

    • Surplus(Excess supply)

      • Definition: It is a situation where quantity demanded is greater than quantity supplied

    • Shortage(Excess demand)

      • Definition: It is a situation where quantity supplied is than quantity demanded

Price change

  • Equilibrium price increases

    • Demand increases

      • Quantity increases

    • Supply decreases

      • Quantity decreases

  • Equilibrium price decrease

    • Demand decreases

      • Quantity decreases

    • Supply increases

      • Quantity increases

Elasticity

PED

  • Definition: It measures the extent to which the quantity demanded changes when the price of the product changes

  • Formula: PED=percentage change in quantity demanded/percentage change in price

    • Sign

      • In the vast majority of cases, it is minus.

    • Size

      • This indicates the extent by which demand will extend or contract when price changes

  • Classification

    • Elastic demand

      • It occurs when a change in price results in a greater percentage change in quantity demanded
      • 1<PED<infinity
      • It is illustrated by a shallow curve
      • An increase in price results in a fall in revenue

    • Inelastic demand

      • It occurs when a change in price results in a smaller percentage change in quantity demanded
      • 0<PED<1
      • It is illustrated by a steep curve
      • An increase in price results in an increase in revenue

    • Perfectly elastic demand

      • It occurs when a change in price causes a complete change in the quantity demanded
      • PED=infinity
      • It is illustrated with a horizontal curve
      • An increase in price results in a fall in revenue

    • Perfectly inelastic demand

      • It occurs when a change in price causes on change in the quantity demanded
      • PED=0
      • It is illustrated with a vertical curve
      • An increase in price results in an increase in revenue

    • Unit elasticity of demand

      • It occurs when a change in price causes an equal change in the quantity demanded, leaving the total revenue unchanged
      • PED=1
      • An increase in price has no effect on revenue

  • Determination

    • Degree of necessity

      • Necessities tend to have a relative inelastic demand

    • Availability of close substitutes

      • Available substitutes result in an elastic demand

    • Proportion of income

      • A high proportion of income tends to result in elastic demand

    • Time period under consideration

      • In long run, consumers have more time to change habit, so it results in elastic demand

    • Addictive goods

      • Addictive goods tend to have an inelastic demand

  • Implications

    • Consumers

      • Benefit from lower prices and higher quality when demand is elastic

    • Producers

      • help them to decide on their pricing strategy
      • try to make the firm’s product more distinctive to make the demand for firm’s product more price inelastic and would give the producer more power to raise price

    • Governments

      • help them make a decision on its subsidy and taxation policies
      • discouraging consumption is more likely to be successful if demand is elastic

PES

  • Definition: It measures the extent to which the quantity supplied changes when the price of the product changes

  • Formula: PES=percentage change in quantity supplied/percentage change in price

    • Sign

      • It is a positive figure

    • Size

      • This indicates the degree of responsiveness of the quantity supplied to a change in price

  • Classification

    • Elastic supply

      • It occurs when the quantity supplied changes by a greater percentage than the change in price
      • 1<PES<infinity
      • It is illustrated by a shallow curve

    • Inelastic supply

      • It occurs when the quantity supplied changes by a smaller percentage than the change in price
      • 0<PES<1
      • It is illustrated by a steep curve

    • Perfectly elastic supply

      • It occurs when a change in price causes a complete change in quantity supplied
      • PES=infinity
      • It is illustrated by a horizontal curve

    • Perfectly inelastic supply

      • It occurs when a change in price has no effect on the quantity supplied
      • PES=0
      • It is illustrated by a vertical curve

    • Unit PES

      • It occurs when a change in price causes an equal percentage change in the quantity supplied

  • Determination

    • Time taken to produce it

      • If it takes a short time producing, the supply is more likely to be price elastic. It is more likely to be price elastic in long run.

    • Number of producers in the industry

      • More suppliers in the industry results in a more elastic supply

    • Feasibility of storing it

      • A higher level of stocks of finished goods results in the supply being more elastic

  • Implications

    • Consumers

      • benefit from supply being elastic

    • Producers

      • benefit from supply being elastic

    • Governments

      • benefit from supply being elastic

Economic system

Three fundamental question

  • What goods and services should be produced? (Three sectors)
  • How should the goods and services be produced?
  • For whom should get the goods and services produced?

Sectors

  • Public sector

    • It is controlled by the government. It covers government run services and state-owned enterprises

  • Private sector

    • It covers business organisations which are owned by shareholders or individuals. These organisation respond to changes in market forces and are profit motivated

Planned Economic

  • Definition: It is an economic system where the government makes the crucial decisions, land and capital are state-owned and resources are allocated by government

Market Economic

  • Basic information

    • Definition: It is an economic system where consumers determine what is produced, resources are allocated by the price mechanism and land and capital are privately owned.

    • Intensive

      • Capital-intensive
      • Labour-intensive

    • Feature

      • Consumer sovereignty
      • Government intervention is minimal
      • Price mechanism

  • Advantages

    • Competitions(to consumers)

      • The nature of a market system determines the levels of competition

      • Advantages

        • Consumer sovereignty
        • Lower prices
        • High quality
        • Many choices

    • Incentives

      • To gain profits and avoid losses(firms)–>try to meet consumers’ needs and wants in order to obtain and maintain consumers
      • To receive high incomes(workers)–>develop skills, work hard, take more responsibility, be more mobile

    • Allocative efficiency（quantity)

      • Firm produce the products that consumers demand in the right quantities
      • Market forces, by changing prices, should eliminate shortages and surpluses and move market towards allocative efficiency.
      • (a competitive market)have both incentive in the form of profit and a threat of punishment in the form of a risk of going out business

    • Production efficiency(Average cost)

      • It produces at the lowest possible average cost
      • (a competitive market)have both incentive and a threat of punishment
      • Producing on PPC

    • Dynamic efficiency(Average costs continue to decrease)

      • The efficiency occurring over time as a result of investment and innovation
      • profit incentive and threat of going out of business

  • Disadvantages

    • Market failure

      • Underproduction(shortage)

      • Overproduction(surplus)

      • Definition: It occurs when market forces of demand and supply fail to produce the right products to the consumers in the right amount and at the lowest cost.(Seen as allocative inefficency)

      • Classification

        • Externality

          • It is the consumption and production of some products may affect third parties(social benefit>private benefit or social cost>private cost)
          • Definition: Social costs are the total costs to a society of an economic activity. Private costs are the costs borne by those directly consuming or producing a product. External costs are costs imposed on third parties
          • Definition: Social benefits are the total benefits to a society of an economic activity. Private benefits are the benefits received by those directly consuming or producing a product. External benefits are benefits enjoyed by the third parties
          • Formula: social=private+external

        • Information failure

          • Needed

            • Consumer

              • nature of the products and the benefits they can receive form them and their prices

            • Workers

              • the jobs, locations, qualifications required, remuneration and the nature of jobs for which their skills are best suited

            • Producers

              • consumer demand, raw material with good quality and lowest prices, most cost-efficient production methods

          • It occurs when there may be a lack of information or inaccurate information.(also called asymmetric information)

        • Merit/Demerit goods

          • Merit

            • Definition: It is the products which the government considers consumers do not fully appreciate how beneficial they are and so which will be under-consumed if left to market forces(positive externality)
            • Solution: Providing subsidy to produces; Government provision; Providing information; Financial incentive for consumers

          • Demerit

            • Definition: It is the products which the governments consider consumers do not fully appreciate how harmful they are and so which will be over-consumed if left to market forces(negative externality)
            • Solution: Increase taxes; Increase advertisement against consumption; Law to limit consumption; Limit import

        • Public goods

          • Features

            • Non-excludability
            • Non-rivalry

        • Abuse of market failure

          • Monopoly; Oligopoly; Monopolistic Competitive
          • No choice but to buy even at high prices
          • Solution: Remove entry barriers; Making uncompetitive practices illegal; Stop firms from merging; Give subsidies to other competition firms; Implement anti-monopoly law

        • Immobility of resouces

          • Occupational immobility
          • Geographical immobility
          • Solution: Improve education and provide training; Provide investment grants; Make it easier to but or rent housing in areas where has a high demand for labour

        • Short termism

          • Market forces may not allocate resources efficiently to enable future generations to be able to enjoy them.

    • Productive inefficiency

      • Producing inside PPC
      • losing market share and profits

    • Dynamic inefficiency

      • Do not do research and development
      • Being driven out of the market

Mixed Economic

  • Basic information

    • Definition: It is an economy in which both the private and public sectors play an important role
    • The degree of public and private sectors is determined by the government
    • Essential services are provided by public sector. Governments exist to redistribute income and wealth
    • In private sector, profit motives the firms to provide goods and services

  • Advantages

    • Eliminate externalities
    • Encourage consumption of merit goods
    • Discourage consumption of demerit goods
    • Provide public goods
    • Prevent high prices(ignore monopoly)
    • Make maximum use of resources
    • A more even distribution of income and wealth

  • Disadvantages(Government failure)

    • Overestimate the extent of private benefits; Difficult to calculate the most efficient quantity of public goods to supply
    • Take time to make decisions; Decisions influenced by political factors
    • Reduce economic efficiency by reducing incentives

  • Actions taken to solve market failure

    • Price ways

      • Maximun prices
      • Minimum prices

    • Non-price ways

      • Indirect taxation

        • Levy an indirect tax on demerit goods to decrease supply in order to reducing demand for these products

      • Subsidies

        • Provide a subsidy to increase supply to encourage the consumption of certain goods and services

      • Regulations

        • Definition: Regulations are rules which are designed to influence the behaviour of firms

      • Educations

      • Nationalisation

        • Definition: It is moving the ownership and control of an industry from the private sector to the government

        • Advantages

          • Decisions on the full costs and benefits involved
          • Be used to influence economic activity
          • Government monopoly will not abuse market power
          • Make planning and coordination easier
          • Ensure basic industries to survive, charge low prices and produce good quality

        • Disadvantages

          • Difficult to manage and control(DOS)
          • Inefficient, produce low quality products and charge relatively high prices, due to a lack of competition and the knowledge that they cannot go bankrupt
          • Need to be subsidised if making loss(OC of government revenue)

      • Privatisation

        • Definition: It is moving the ownership and control of an industry from the government to the private sector

        • Advantages

          • The ability to earn one-off privatisation proceeds from the sale of state-owned assets.
          • Reduce government debts(No longer has to maintain the operation; earns revenue from selling the business; earns taxes)
          • Reduce costs to taxpayers
          • Incentive to improve efficiency, risking taking and innovation

        • Disadvantages

          • Consumers may face higher prices
          • To protect the public interest, privatisation may still require government regulation and intervention.
          • OC（State-owned enterprises provide social benefits)

      • Direct provision

        • Definition: Governments provide certain goods and services free of charge to their citizens

        • Advantages

          • The goods and services are accessible to all people in society
          • private benefits for the individual and external benefits for third parties in society

        • Disadvantages

          • OC
          • Free goods and services may be over-consumed
          • In the case of a shortage of supply caused by excess demand, it can be difficult to decide who should be able to take advantage of the free government service.
          • Free riders take advantage of free goods and services without contributing to government revenue by paying taxes.

Economy

Economy is that people and firms produce, exchange and consume goods and services

Microeconomics is the study of the behaviour and decisions of households and firms and the performance of individual markets.

Macroeconomics is the study of the whole economy.

Decision makers

  • Also called economic agents

  • Household

    • including consumers, savers and workers
    • Consumers aim at low price and good quality products
    • Workers aim at good working conditions and high pay
    • Savers aim at their money to be safe and to give a good return

  • Firm

    • They are the business concerns that produce goods and services and employ workers and other FOPs
    • Firms(in private sector)aim at making as much profit as possible

  • Government

    • It is the system which rules a country or region. It produces and provides some products, financial benefits, and levies taxes on and regulates the private sector
    • Government aims at a strong economy and improve the performance of individual markets

entry.title: IGCSE Economics Mind Map Section6 International Trade and Globalisation
entry.content:
Specialisation and free trade

Classification of specialisation

  • Definition: It occurs when individuals, firms, regions or countries concentrate on the production of a particular good or service.

  • Individuals

    • Become more skilled and efficient at their jobs, and increase both quality and quantity of the goods and serviced produced

  • Firms

  • Regions

  • Countries

    • Definition: International specialisation occurs when countries concentrate on the production of certain goods or services due to cost advantages (cheaper production methods) and their abundance of superior resources.
    • Influenced by the quantity and quality of their resources

Advantages of specialisation

  • For consumers

    • Enjoy more goods and services and higher living standards as an increase in output
    • Better quality of the product as an improvement in skills and techniques
    • Lower price as the average costs of production decrease

  • For firms

    • Take the advantages of economies of scale
    • Be able to buy raw materials from specialist firms which are producing high quality raw materials at low costs
    • Trade helps firms in the exchange of new management ideas, information about the new products and new technology

  • For the economy

    • Increase efficiency and economic welfare
    • Real GDP should be relative high and output would be higher
    • Consume outside its PPC
    • Consume more goods and services to raise living standards and reduce relative poverty
    • Resources will not be lying idle
    • Keep inflation rate relatively low
    • Build up reputation in producing particular product to attract more sales and ancillary industries to set up in the country and boost its sales of exports

Disadvantages of specialisation

  • For consumers

    • One or some countries may gain control of most of the global market and restrict supply to push up the price
    • May not follow the same health and safety standards as the home country
    • Any problems happened in the country may stop the country from producing so in the short run the product is not available

  • For firms

    • Too dependent on other counties for the markets of the products they produce and for the sources of their raw materials
    • May experience a fall in demand as tastes may change or foreign counties become more efficient or a substitute may be developed

  • For the economy

    • Hard to determine what an economy is best at producing and what will be in demand in the future
    • If demand suddenly falls or costs rise, the country may run into difficulties and results in structural unemployment
    • High transport costs may also offset any costs advantage a country has in producing

Absolute&Comparative advantage

  • Definition: Absolute advantage is a country can produce the product using fewer resources than other countries
  • Definition: Comparative advantage is a country can produce the product at a lower opportunity costs than other countries

Trade

  • Definition: International trade refers to the exchange of goods and services beyond national borders. It entails the sale of exports (goods and services sold to overseas buyers) and imports (foreign goods and services bought by domestic households and firms).

  • Definition: Free trade means that international trade can take place without any forms of protection (barriers to international trade), such as quantitative limits or taxes being imposed on exports.

    • Advantages

  • Connection between specialisation and international trade

    • Producing a relatively narrow range of products will mean that countries will have to export some of their output. This is necessary for them to gain revenue for spending on imports of products that their citizens want to buy, but their countries are not producing

  • Globalisation

    • Definition: Globalisation is the process by which the world’s economies become increasingly interdependent and interconnected due to greater international trade and cultural exchanges.

    • Consequences

      • Advantages

        • With increasing international trade, creating wealth and jobs throughout the world
        • Increasing competition results in more products at relatively low prices
        • Encourage firms to locate their production in most efficient locations
        • Freer movement of labour, capital, goods and services
        • Firms can enjoy economies of scale
        • More choices of goods and services
        • Greater cultural understanding and appreciation

      • Disadvantages

        • Greater dependence on global economy(A recession in one economy can have significant impact on other economies)
        • Some workers may lose their jobs because of increased competition
        • Increase the importance of occupational mobility

    • Multinational company(MNC)

      • An MNC in an organisation that operates in two or more countries.

      • Advantages

        • Foreign country–Through job creation, improve standards of living in the countries
        • Firms&consumers–MNCs enjoy economies of scale so MNCs can pass on cost savings to their consumers in form of lower prices
        • Firms&home country–By operating in overseas market, MNCs are able to generate more profits because of an increase in consumer base(profit are repatriated so home country benefits)
        • Firms&foreign country–MNCs move or expand their operations in foreign countries to benefit from lower rates of corporation tax.
        • Firms–Spread risks by operating overseas
        • Firms–Avoid any trade restrictions
        • Firms–Access new markets by locating overseas and reduce transportation costs

      • Disadvantages

        • Workers–Unethical and cost-cutting practises
        • Local companies–MNCs can force local firms that are less competitive to close down because of their huge market power and ability to exploit economies of scale
        • Local government–They are often in a powerful position to exploit foreign governments over decisions
        • Local country–Higher unemployment
        • Local country–Over-reliance on MNCs in low income countries means there are major consequences should an MNC choose to relocate the operation
        • MNCs– Hard to manage the overall business because of a lack of effective communications
        • MNCs– Fluctuating exchange rate makes it difficult to measure and compare the value of MNCs’ sales and profits
        • MNCs– May not provide goods and services appealed to local tastes and consumers

Protection

Definition: Protection refers to the use of trade barriers to restrict foreign trade, thereby limiting overseas competition

Methods

  • Tariff

    • It is a tax on imports.
    • Tariff increases the cost of production and the price of imports in domestic market, so the quantity of imports reduces

  • Import quotas

    • It sets a quantitative limit on the scale of a foreign goods in a country.
    • Quota limits the quantity imported

  • Subsidies

    • Government can provide subsidies to domestic firms to compete against importers
    • Subsidies lower the costs of production for home firms

  • Embargo

    • It is a ban on trade with a certain country, due to a trade dispute or political conflict
    • An embargo rarely benefits local consumers as they suffer from a lack of choices and higher prices

  • Exchange control

    • A government try to decrease import through restricting the availability of foreign currency

  • Quality standards

    • A country may ask imports to reach artificially high standards results in dissuading other countries from selling or pushing up prices

  • Expensive paperwork

    • Require foreign firms to fill out a considerable amount of time-consuming paperwork

  • Voluntary export restraints(VERs)

    • A government may persuade the foreign government to agree to restrict the number of units of a product sold by it

Consequences

  • Advantages

    • Help the infant industries from foreign competition and safeguard domestic jobs, because in extreme cases, fierce competition from foreign rivals can even force domestic firms out of business.
    • Prevent foreign countries dumping(occurs when foreign firms sell their products in large quantities at prices deliberately below those charged by domestic firms, often even below the cost of production)
    • Increase government revenue
    • Overcome a balance of payment deficit as restricting imports will help to deal with it
    • To protect strategic industries instead of relying on foreign countries

  • Disadvantages

    • Government intervention may distort market signals and results in an international misallocation of resources. The domestic companies may become too reliant on government and become inefficient
    • Decreasing competition and incentive for innovation may lead to an increase in price. Costs of raw materials may increase as well and results in imported inflation
    • Other countries may react with retaliating and imposing their own barriers. This may hinder global economic growth and prosperity

Balance of payment

Capital Account

Financial Account

Current Account

  • Definition

    • This is a record of all exports and imports of goods and services between a country and the rest of the world, plus net income transfers from abroad.

  • Components

    • Trade in goods(visible)

      • Definition: It is the value of exported goods and the value of the imported goods

      • Example: UK retailers buy chocolate from Belgium

      • Results

        • Trade in goods deficit

          • expenditure on imported goods<revenue from exported goods

        • Trade in goods surplus

          • expenditure on imported goods>revenue from exported goods

    • Trade in services(invisible)

      • Definition: It is the value of exported services and the value of imported services

      • Example: American tourists fly to the UK on British Airways

      • Results

        • Trade in services deficit

          • expenditure on imported services<revenue from exported services

        • Trade in services surplus

          • expenditure on imported services>revenue from exported services

    • Primary income

      • Definition: It is the income earned by people working in different countries and investment income which comes into and goes out of the country
      • Example: Money sent home by people working abroad

    • Secondary income

      • Definition: It is the transfers between residents and non-residents of money, goods or services, not in return for anything else
      • Example: Scholarships paid to students based in overseas universities

  • Deficit

    • Definition: A current account deficit occurs when its import expenditure is greater than its export earnings(the current account has a negative balance)

    • Causes

      • Lower demand for exports

        • A decline in manufacturing competitiveness(may caused by higher labour costs domestically)
        • A decline income in foreign market(may due to a decrease in available money caused by an economic recession)
        • An increase in exchange rate which makes exports more expensive and reduce the volume and value of exports

      • Higher demand for imports

        • Cheaper or better quality of imports(cheaper may due to a decrease in exchange rate)
        • Domestic inflation which makes imports relatively cheaper

    • Consequences

      • Advantages

        • Lower exchange rate

          • The demand for the domestic currency decreases so the exchange rate decreases and exports become more competitive

      • Disadvantages

        • Reduced demand

          • As the economy is spending more on imports that it is receiving, the demand in economy will fall and a recession may be triggered

        • Unemployment

          • A fall in overall demand may cause cyclical unemployment. Also, the wages may decrease

        • Lower standards of living

          • The deficit may be caused by capital outflows exceed capital inflows. The economy may suffer from lower standards of living as income is less. Also, households and firms may need to reduce spending

        • Increased borrowing

          • Deficit means spending more than income. Government needs to borrow money to overcome the difference which results in interest and repayment of the loan(any money which government spends has an opportunity cost)

  • Surplus

    • Definition: A current account deficit occurs when its export earning is greater than its import expenditure(the current account has a positive balance)

    • Causes

      • High demand for exports

        • An improvement in manufacturing competitiveness(may caused by higher labour productivity in domestic economy)
        • Higher incomes in overseas markets
        • A decrease in exchange rate

      • Low demand for imports

        • Imports are more expensive or of a lower quality
        • Inflation in overseas countries causes import tend to be expensive

    • Consequences

      • Advantages

        • A fall in unemployment in domestic economy, but an increase in unemployment in other countries
        • The country receive high income because the home country has a competitive advantage in the product they export and result in a better living standards

      • Disadvantages

        • Higher demand for exports may lead to demand-pull inflation and diminish the international competitiveness
        • Higher demand for exports can cause the currency to appreciate in value and foreign buyers will find it more expensive to import goods into their countries.

  • Policies to achieve balance of payment stability

    • Fiscal policy

      • Higher taxes and reduced government spending to decrease the amount of money available to spend on imports

    • Monetary policy

      • Floating–Higher interest rates make new and existing loans more expensive for households and firms to reduce demand for imports
      • Fixed– The central monetary authority of a country might decide to devalue the exchange rate to improve the nation’s competitiveness

    • Supply-side policy

      • To raise the productive capacity
      • Investment in education and healthcare services to improve human capital, productivity and competitiveness
      • Investment in infrastructure to support
      • Encourage export-drive business start-ups and industries

    • Protectionist measuers

      • Reduce the competitiveness imports, thereby making domestic consumption more attractive

Exchange rate

Definition: An exchange rate refers to the price of one currency measured in terms of other currencies.

Determination

  • Demand for currency

    • This means that as the value of a country’s currency rises, its demand for imports tends to increase.

  • Supply of currency

Floating exchange rate

  • Definition: In floating exchange rate, the value of the currency is determined by the market forces of demand for the currency and supply of the currency

  • Change in exchange rate

    • Definition: An appreciation in the exchange rate if the exchange rate is rising against other currencies
    • Definition: A depreciation in the exchange rate if the exchange rate is falling against other currencies

Fixed exchange rate

  • Definition: In a fixed exchange rate system, the government intervenes in foreign exchange markets to maintain its exchange rate at a predetermined level

  • Main advantage: reducing the uncertainties for international trade makes domestic and foreign firms to be certain about future costs and prices and encourages international trade and exchange

  • This is achieved by the respective government buying and selling foreign currencies

  • Change in exchange rate

    • Definition: A revaluation in the exchange rate if the exchange rate is rising against other currencies
    • Definition: A devaluation in the exchange rate if the exchange rate is falling against other currencies

Causes of exchange rate fluctuations

  • Floating exchange rate system

    • Changes in demand for exports: An increase in the demand for export will increase the demand for the country’s currency and increase the exchange rate

    • Changes in demand for imports: An increase in the demand for import will increase the demand for foreign currency and increase the value of foreign currency

    • Prices and inflation: An increase in the price of goods and services caused by domestic inflation will decrease the demand for exports

    • Foreign direct investment(FDI): Investment in overseas production plant requires the use of foreign currencies

      • Inward FDI(eg. the entry of an MNC)will boost the demand for a currency
      • Outward FDI(eg. departure of an MNC)will increase the supply of a currency

    • Speculation: foreign exchange traders and investment companies move money around the world to take advantage of higher interest rates and variations in exchange rates to earn a profit. As huge sums of money(hot money)are involved, speculation can cause exchange rate fluctuations. They might lack confidence and therefore withdraw their investment and depreciate the currency

  • Fixed exchange rate system

    • Government intervention

Consequences of appreciation and revaluation

  • Advantages

    • Consumers will have greater purchasing power
    • Importers gain from a strong dollar because the raw materials, components and finished goods will be cheaper. But this is bad for domestic producers
    • As unemployment decreases, the inflation rate will decrease. Also, if the country relies heavily on imports, the higher exchange rate will reduce general price level

  • Disadvantages

    • Exporters may face difficulties as exchange rate increases caused by their goods and services become more expensive for foreign consumers
    • A fall in net exports and deteriorating profits will cause job losses in export-oriented businesses and increase unemployment
    • In the long run, as a result of the higher exchange rate, economic growth is likely to fall due to the combination of lower export sales and higher unemployment.
    • If a currency appreciation has a larger impact on exports than imports (that is, there is a fall in the value of net exports), then the balance of payments will worsen, as a strong currency will make it more difficult for exporters to sell their goods and services in overseas markets.

Coping with a strong exchange rate

  • Cutting export prices to maintain their price competitiveness against foreign rivals
  • Seeking alternative suppliers of cheaper raw materials
  • Improving productivity to keep costs of production low
  • Provide more price inelastic demand products as consumers are not sensitive with price change caused by exchange fluctuations
  • Improving non-price factors, including brand awareness and social responsibility
  • Relocate the production process overseas
